data.title: Honolulu (1939)
data.meta_description: Wanting a break from his overzealous fans, a famous movie star hires a Hawaiian plantation owner to switch places with him for a few weeks.
data.text:
Musical MAYhem, track 12

The old trading places gambit, back in '30s musical land. A movie star asks a guy who happens to look just like him if they can switch for a while so the actor can get some peace and quiet out in Hawaii, where his doppleganger lives and apparently the press hadn't yet discovered (to be fair, this was 20 years before it even became an American state). Both men, played by one of the thousands of affable leading man Roberts in pre-mid century Hollywood (quick tell me the difference between Robert Young, Robert Cummings and Robert Montgomery, because I conflate them all whenever either shows up in a movie), get into unexpected hijinks and romance, needless…

I went into this expecting a musical... i was not expecting a comedy as well, and that made for a very pleasant surprise even when I thought the plot was a bit weak. I'm not entirely won over by Robert Young's performance, but Eleanor Powell does a good job here, and I find something very charming any time Gracie Allen is in something, as she was hands down the best comic performance here (I'd expected more from George Burns, really).

There's a lot of great comedy bits, but this film really hits a 5 star segment when it gets to the celebrity costume event on the ship. Firstly, I just really enjoy all the celebrities and characters that are getting…
